definitions.definition: used before countable or singular nouns referring to people or things that have not already been mentioned

examples.text: I can only carry two at a time.
She's a friend of my father's *(= one of my father's friends)*.

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody/something is a member of a group or profession

examples.text: Is that a Monet *(= a painting by Monet)*?
A lion is a dangerous animal.

definitions.definition: used before uncountable nouns when these have an adjective in front of them, or phrase following them

examples.text: a sadness that won’t go away

definitions.definition: used in front of two nouns that are seen as a single unit
used instead of one before some numbers
used when talking about prices, quantities and rates

examples.text: I can type 50 words a minute.
He was driving at 50 miles an hour.

definitions.definition: used before somebody’s name to show that the speaker does not know the person

examples.text: There's a Mrs Green to see you.

definitions.definition: used before the names of days of the week to talk about one particular day

wordOrigin: Middle English: weak form of Old English ān ‘one’.
